column2: Now that the British former socialite Ghislaine Maxwell has been convicted in her sex-trafficking trial, speculation is growing that she may try to cut a deal and become a government witness in any broader investigation into the elite social circle of her ex-boyfriend Jeffrey Epstein.  Maxwell would be aiming for a reduced sentence by naming powerful names when it comes to others who may be involved in Epsteinâ€™s crimes. But defense lawyers and sexual-crimes prosecutors have cast doubt on the governmentâ€™s appetite to strike a bargain. They question whether Maxwell has any vital information the government does not already have, and whether it represents a strategy Maxwell has previously attempted that has failed. â€œIt all depends on who she would be cooperating against, and what she has to offer,â€ said Jeffrey Lichtman, the defense attorney who represented the Mexican drug trafficker JoaquÃ­n â€œEl Chapoâ€ GuzmÃ¡n at trial two years ago. â€œI would not be surprised if she had already tried to cooperate and it had failed.â€ Maxwell, who is expected to appeal her conviction, was found guilty on five of six charges for her involvement in Epsteinâ€™s sexual abuse of teenage girls. Prosecutors said Maxwell â€œpreyed on vulnerable young girls, manipulated them and served them up to be sexually abusedâ€. She is expected to receive a significant prison term. According to Lichtman, there are defendants who, in the eyes of the government, are so bad that it does not want to strike a deal in exchange for testimony. â€œThey donâ€™t want to take the hand of someone involved a criminal operation and let them cooperate against people who are well below them.â€ â€œThat may be the case here â€“ they just feel that sheâ€™s so bad they wonâ€™t allow her to cooperate,â€ Lichtman said. But that does not preclude Maxwell and her lawyers from making an offer. â€œThereâ€™s a tremendous amount of information she has on some very important people. Now that sheâ€™s been convicted she may be more eager to discuss. She certainly should, in my mind, because a lot of people skated here, while she bore the brunt of the governmentâ€™s full wrath,â€ Lichtman said. Former federal and state prosecutor Elie Honig said on Twitter: â€œMaxwellâ€™s cooperation is not particularly likely, but it is possible. Youâ€™d need (1) Maxwell to be willing and fully on board, (2) SDNY to be fully convinced of her truthfulness, and (3) a realistic plan to use her information versus others.â€ One obstacle to any state prosecution based on Maxwellâ€™s cooperation would be the statute of limitations on criminal and civil sexual crime complaints. The civil case bought by Virginia Giuffre against Britainâ€™s Prince Andrew only exists because of a briefly opened window under the New York Child Victims Act, which allowed accusers to sue beyond the statute of limitations. But there is also pressure for high-profile visitors to Epsteinâ€™s properties in New York, Palm Beach and the the US Virgin Islands to be held accountable for any potential crimes, particularly as the governmentâ€™s case against Maxwell appeared to avoid reference to broader aspects of the conspiracy. â€œOf all the people supposedly involved with Epstein, 99% of them never made it into the governmentâ€™s evidence,â€ said Lichtman. â€œPerhaps they were trying to avoid any frolic by the jury â€“ that theyâ€™d get distracted by the bold-face names â€“ but many people didnâ€™t get prosecuted here when it seems like they could have,â€ he added. According to Wendy Murphy, a former federal sex crimes prosecutor who now teaches at Boston Law, the relative absence of Epstein from Maxwellâ€™s conspiracy trial was part of the governmentâ€™s strategy. â€œThey didnâ€™t need more to prove conspiracy,â€ she said. â€œThey didnâ€™t need to overdo it. There was some weakness in the victims testimony but it was more than offset by other evidence.â€ The next chapter of the Epstein case, Murphy said, is likely to come through the civil action against Prince Andrew. â€œPrince Andrew may be the next shoe to drop, and it may be the only shoe,â€ she said. The windows have closed on lawsuits for the most part, and I donâ€™t know of another lawsuit with the potential to expose information.â€ But if more investigations do happen, Murphy said Maxwell could get time off her sentence if the government wants important information she has. â€œIâ€™m not sure the feds are asking and Iâ€™m not sure sheâ€™s willing to give. Sheâ€™s probably not going to say anything, and they donâ€™t need her to, because they already have a lot of information. If they donâ€™t need anything, theyâ€™re not going to give her a discount.â€ Ultimately, said Bennett Gershman, professor of law at Pace University in New York, much depends on whether the government feels there is political mileage in continuing the investigation and identifying high-profile people who may have been part of the scheme. â€œItâ€™s hard to say what the government is interested in further on. We canâ€™t answer that. Are the victims and people who really care about this case satisfied now Maxwell has been convicted or do they want to see other people in the larger network investigated?â€ He added: â€œThey have limited resources and personnel, so does this case cry out for further investigation and prosecution? Thatâ€™s a political decision by the US department of justice and the US attorneyâ€™s office.â€

column2: A coroner will investigate the deaths of two women from herpes following childbirth, amid fears they contracted the virus from their surgeon. Kim Sampson, 29, and Samantha Mulcahy, 32, died weeks apart after their babies were delivered by caesarean section at different hospitals in Kent.  Their families have campaigned for answers as to whether they contracted the infection from their surgeon, after a BBC investigation found the women were treated by the same person. The inquests have been listed to open and adjourn in Maidstone on 4 January, with a pre-inquest review the following month and full inquests at a later date. Sampsonâ€™s mother, Yvette, said: â€œWeâ€™ve wanted this since Kim died in 2018 â€“ itâ€™s been a long time coming. We hope we are finally going to get answers to the questions weâ€™ve always had â€“ both for ourselves and for Kimâ€™s children.â€ Herpes infections are commonly found in the genitals and on the face, often with mild symptoms. Sampsonâ€™s baby boy, her second child, was delivered at Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother hospital in Margate in May 2018, but she died at the end of the month in hospital in London after becoming infected. In July the same year, first-time mother Mulcahy died from an infection caused by the virus at William Harvey hospital in Ashford. Dr Rebecca Martin, chief medical officer for East Kent hospitals, said: â€œOur deepest sympathies are with the families and friends of Kimberley and Samantha. â€œWe will do everything possible to support these inquests and our thoughts are with Kimberley and Samanthaâ€™s families at this time.â€ A coroner had previously ruled out inquests into their deaths but now this decision has been reversed. The families had initially received a letter from coroner Katrina Hepburn saying there would not be an inquest for either case, acknowledging the similarities but saying there was â€œno connectionâ€. Sampson had a good pregnancy but struggled with the birth and she kept saying the baby was stuck, her mother said. Doctors performed a C-section to deliver her son and Sampson needed a blood transfusion after injuries sustained in the operation. She was rushed back to hospital following discharge after the operation as doctors believed she had bacterial sepsis. She was given antibiotics, but her condition worsened. Mulcahy went into labour four weeks ahead of her due date. Her hospital was part of the same trust as that where Sampson was treated. She had 17 hours of contractions and was taken for a C-section after some worrying blood test results. After giving birth, Mulcahy was kept in for observation. She became increasingly unwell, and doctors also thought she had bacterial sepsis. She spent four days in intensive care, where a doctor suggested antiviral medication, but the microbiology department advised them to continue with antibiotics. Mulcahy died from multi-organ failure following a â€œdisseminated herpes simplex type 1 infectionâ€, a postmortem found. Both women had a â€œprimary infectionâ€ which means that this was the first time they had contracted the virus and neither of their children were found to have it. Sampsonâ€™s family requested documents from Public Health England which revealed emails from the trust, some NHS bodies, staff at PHE, and a private lab. The messages showed that the same two clinicians â€“ a midwife and the surgeon who carried out the C-sections â€“ had been involved in both births.
column4: Inquests to be held into deaths of new mothers who died from herpes

column2: Hospitality bosses have urged consumers not to desert their local pub during â€œdry Januaryâ€, the month when many people abstain from alcohol, as hard-hit venues struggle to recover from a nightmare Christmas. Takings over the crucial festive weeks have fallen by as much as 60% compared with the same period in 2019, making this the second year in a row that pubs, bars and restaurants have lost out during the most lucrative time of the year.  The slump means venues have not built up the cash reserves they need to survive the typically quiet January and February, piling pressure on a sector already reeling from pandemic-related losses and ballooning rent debts. Several leading figures in the hospitality industry told the Guardian that pubs would fall into even greater financial difficulty unless people kept visitingthem during January, the annual month when some people choose to stop drinking. Kate Nicholls, the chief executive of the trade body UK Hospitality, said: â€œI think we could definitely dispense with it [dry January].â€ She called on people who are trying to avoid alcohol to consider choosing something else at the bar or going out for food. â€œThis year, there are an awful lot more non-alcoholic options available that are really good quality, so thereâ€™s no excuse not to go out and support your local hospitality business.â€ Greg Mulholland, the Campaign for Pubs director, said: â€œPubs and publicans will need support throughout January and weâ€™d urge people to continue to go to the pub. â€œThe pub is about so much more than having a drink, so we hope people recognise the important role pubs play in our communities and get out and support them, whatever they choose to drink and eat.â€ He also stressed the improved availability of non-alcoholic options in the UKâ€™s network of pubs, the number of which has been in decline in recent years and currently stands at about 47,000. Concern about alcohol intake has increased during the pandemic, following a Public Health England report that detailed a rise in problem-drinking deaths associated with successive lockdowns. However, the report found that the steepest rise in alcohol sales came from people drinking at home during lockdowns that forced hospitality venues to close. Paul Crossman, who runs three pubs in York including The Swan, said it was still possible for people to order at the bar without compromising their health goals. â€œIt would be much appreciated if people did forego dry January, but loads of us have really good alcohol-free options too. Itâ€™s about supporting local hospitality businesses so that they can get through it,â€ he said. The pub group Fullerâ€™s was forced to close several venues earlier this month as a result of slow trade, partly because its portfolio of more than 380 pubs and inns is weighted towards London, where cases of the Omicron Covid variant have soared and work-from-home guidance has left parts of the city deserted. The chief executive of Fullerâ€™s, Simon Emeny, said he hoped there would be â€œenormous pent-up demandâ€ after people sacrificed pre-Christmas nights out to ensure they could still see family. He pointed out that while the aims of dry January, promoted by Alcohol Change UK, are laudable, there is conflicting opinion about whether itâ€™s the right approach to counteracting overindulgence. â€œMedical evidence says that drinking in moderation is more sensible than abstaining for an entire month,â€ Emeny said. â€œI do think that having been denied the opportunity to mix and socialise, a lot of people will say theyâ€™ll make up for lost time and be more sociable in January.â€ While many pubs fear a downturn in January partly due to people choosing not to drink Peter Marks, who runs the UKâ€™s largest bar and nightclub business Rekom UK, said young people were less likely to abstain. â€œTheyâ€™ll take a couple of weekends for their wallet to recover from Christmas and New Year, but as long as students come back in that third week of January, we never see any effect from dry January,â€ he said.
column4: Keep going to pubs during dry January, UK hospitality bosses urge

column2: The health secretary, Sajid Javid, is being urged to ensure NHS workers are prioritised for Covid tests or risk a â€œdevastatingâ€ impact on patient care, after conceding to MPs that the supply of lateral flow kits would have to be â€œconstrainedâ€ over the next fortnight in light of rocketing demand. The British Medical Association (BMA), which represents doctors, warned that the system for ensuring NHS staff receive tests was â€œnot workingâ€. It said its members were reporting problems with obtaining PCR and lateral flow tests, despite healthcare workers supposedly being given priority for both.  The BMAâ€™s chair of council, Dr Chaand Nagpaul, said: â€œBeing unable to get the tests means staff may not be legally allowed to work and, at a time of acute workforce shortages and winter pressures, this could be devastating for the care that can be given right across the NHS.â€ Demand for tests has been surging in recent days, with new infections increasing rapidly and ministers, including the prime minister, Boris Johnson, advising the public to test themselves before attending New Yearâ€™s Eve parties or meeting vulnerable relatives. Another factor boosting demand is that the self-isolation period in England was recently cut from 10 days to seven, but only with two negative lateral flow tests. Official figures showed that 189,213 new cases were reported in the UK in the 24 hours to 9am on Thursday, and 332 people died within 28 days of a positive Covid test although this included hospital death figures from England since 24 December. NHS statistics showed 11,452 people in England were in hospital with Covid-19 as of the morning of December 30, up 61% in a week â€“ and the highest number since 26 February. Javid has acknowledged in a letter to MPs that the supply of lateral flow tests may have to be constrained over the next fortnight. â€œIn light of the huge demand for LFDs [lateral flow devices] seen over the last three weeks, we expect to need to constrain the system at certain points over the next two weeks to manage supply over the course of each day, with new tranches of supply released regularly throughout each day,â€ he wrote on Wednesday night. The shadow health secretary, Wes Streeting, has written to Javid calling on him to make sure healthcare workers are given priority. â€œI urge you to put the key workers we have relied upon for the past two years to the front of the queue and do everything you can to prevent a staffing shortage crisis in our NHS. The government must get a grip on this crisis, bring these shortages to an end, and ensure everyone can access tests quickly and regularly,â€ he wrote. A Department of Health and Social Care spokesperson rejected the idea that healthcare workers had been unable to obtain tests, saying they had their own dedicated supply channel. Azeem Majeed, a professor of primary care and public health at Imperial College London, said the government was â€œin part to blameâ€ for the shortage of tests because of its advice to the public to test themselves before social events and outings. â€œIt has become very clear that there are nowhere nearly enough lateral flow tests for Covid-19 in England to allow the governmentâ€™s policy of their indiscriminate use,â€ he said in an article in the Guardian. He called for the publication of daily data on how many tests are available, and then â€œclear guidance from the government on what groups should be prioritised for testing and how frequently they should testâ€. The Welsh government announced on Thursday that it had lent an additional 4m lateral flow testing kits to England to help alleviate the supply squeeze across the border, bringing the total offered to 10m. The National Education Union (NEU) has called for teachers to be among the groups given priority, amid concerns about whether sufficient tests will available as the new term starts next week. Mary Bousted, the joint general secretary of the NEU, said: â€œIf schools are the top priority, as Boris Johnson has said they are, there is a case for teachers being a priority group so that they can test themselves, so they can be in school educating pupils.â€ With all secondary pupils expected to be tested before they start the spring term next week, the Liberal Democrats have urged the education secretary, Nadhim Zahawi, to ensure every school has enough tests in place. The Lib Dem education spokesperson, Munira Wilson, said: â€œNadhim Zahawi must provide a cast-iron guarantee that every child and teacher who needs a Covid test will be able to access one on the first day of term, to avoid yet more disruption to schools next week. We cannot afford a repeat of last yearâ€™s fiasco when pupils returned for one day before being sent home again.â€ A Department for Education spokesperson said the government had delivered 28m test kits to schools in the final two weeks of last term. â€œSchools and colleges use a different priority supply route to get their lateral flow tests. Most kits have already been received for the start of the new term and we have emergency arrangements in place to make sure every school has the testing it needs,â€ the spokesperson said. One south London headteacher, Ben Roberts, of Heathbrook primary school in Lambeth, said his school had ordered tests from the DfE two weeks before the end of term and was yet to receive them. He said he had been touring local pharmacies trying to obtain test kits. â€œWe were expecting staff to go in for an inset day on Tuesday. If staff havenâ€™t had a test prior to that, all weâ€™re doing is super-spreading again. So I for the last few days have been trying every which way to get hold of any more.â€ The Pharmaceutical Services Negotiating Committee (PSNC), which represents NHS community pharmacies in England, said some pharmacy staff were being verbally abused when stocks of lateral flow tests ran out. Alastair Buxton, the PSNCâ€™s director of NHS services, said: â€œPublic demand for test kits remains exceptionally high and, despite UKHSA delivering some 2m tests to pharmacy wholesalers on some days, this is still falling short of demand. Members of the public being directed to pharmacies for tests are rightly frustrated when they cannot get them, but itâ€™s concerning that some pharmacy teams say they are still being verbally abused when this happens.â€ A government spokesperson said: â€œThe NHS has additional stock of lateral flow tests and those who live or work in vulnerable settings have access to dedicated testing order routes. If at some point it is necessary to do so we will always prioritise protecting the most vulnerable as well as critical workforces, as we have done throughout the pandemic when it comes to vaccines, boosters, testing and other infection control measures such as PPE.â€
column4: Javid urged to prioritise Covid tests for NHS workers or risk patient harm

column2: The legendary British sprinter Ron Jones, who captained Team GB at the Mexico Olympics in 1968 and was part of the 4x110yd team that equalled the world record in 1963, has died at the age of 87. After his illustrious track and field career, Jones moved into football, first as the chief executive of QPR in 1976 before becoming managing director at Cardiff and then Portsmouth.  But he will be best remembered for being part of the British team â€“ alongside Peter Radford, David Jones and Berwyn Jones â€“ who stunned a strong US contingent to equal the world 4x110yd record in 40.0 secs. Writing in the Observer, Norris McWhirter said the performance was so good it made â€œthe White City crowd explode with joy â€“ just like in the old daysâ€. The feat was even more impressive given the US team that day included Bob â€œThe Bulletâ€ Hayes, the worldâ€™s fastest man who would later win gold at the 1964 Olympics. It was a measure of Jonesâ€™s quality that when he faced Hayes in the individual 100yd dash earlier that afternoon he pushed him to the line. â€œThe mighty Hayes, who breaks all the rules of fast movement by rocking and rolling as he fights his pigeon-toed way down the track, was expected to pull away,â€ wrote McWhirter. â€œBut nothing of the sort happened. In fact Jones fractionally closed on him and was only beaten by two foot on the tape.â€ Hayesâ€™s time was 9.5s, with Jonesâ€™s 9.6s. Such was Jonesâ€™s form that year he also set a Welsh 100m record of 10.30s â€“ which stood for 27 years until it was beaten by Colin Jackson in 1990. His great friend Lynn Davies, who won long jump gold in Tokyo 1964 and ran in the GB relay team with Jones in those Olympics, told the Guardian that Jones was an â€œinspirational character on and off the trackâ€. â€œRon will be remembered for being one of Walesâ€™s greatest ever athletes,â€ he said. â€œHe was one of my heroes growing up and when we raced I could never beat him. He had such a smooth stride. And, remarkably, he did it all while working full-time as an accountant.â€ Davies said that, when Jones was managing director at Cardiff City, he would even take fitness training with the players. â€œAnd he also did a great deal for young people in sport in Wales as chairman of Sports Aid Cymru Wales.â€ â€œHe was a very proud Welshman with a very warm and outgoing personality,â€ he added. â€œHe loved company, and a glass of red wine. I have many happy memories of sitting with him and reminiscing about the good old days.â€
column4: Ron Jones, sprinter and British captain at Mexico Olympics, dies aged 87
